temperature.title: Temperature
temperature.content: Echinococcus spp. eggs can be inactivated by heat (e.g., 70°C for 30 minutes, boiling), by freezing at -80°C for 48 hours or –70°C for 4 days. They are particularly sensitive to a combination of elevated temperatures and desiccation: 90% of eggs placed in direct sunlight on a petri dish may become nonviable within a day.

oxygen.title: Oxygen
oxygen.content: The eggs can remain viable in the environment under aerobic condition and can be infective up to 3 years.

humidity.title: Water
humidity.content: Echinococcus spp. eggs need high humidity to survive, at least 70%. Drying out is the primary factor that leads to the death of eggs.
